title: Is the “self” different from the “mind”? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes. I'll explain (citation at the end): That the self is more than mindWe do have some stream of consciousness. The mind is conscious, and I have a mind. Descartes pretty reasonably proved that. However, this stream of consciousness (“mind”) is connected to this body. This is not to say that it must be true that all streams of consciousnessess are bodily, but that, in this case, this body is attached in some way to this stream of consciousness (mind). We know this because the body is the center of consciousness for this mind, but most interestingly because this body withholds information only from that mind; only I can't see the back of my head. So, the unity of bodily experience and phenomenal experience is greater than the mind, though dependent on the mind. This unity is a “psycho-physical unity” that is at least part of the self, and this unity is more than mind. 2. What is the self? The self, then is the unity of the experiences performed by the psycho-physical unity (the “I”). Basically, who I am is the totality of all of my experiences (and their interrelations) which is a result of being a psycho-physical unity. Essentially, the self exists in the mind but it is different because the stream of consciousness which IS the mind is (in this case) dependent on a body for the physical or bodily experience which also makes up the self. So, the self exists as phenomenon in the mind but the mental phenomena (in the mind and as an action of it) is distinct from physical phenomena (in the mind but as an action of the physical). For the full argument: Edith Stein’s “On the Problem of Empathy”, section on constitution of psycho-physical unity.
